solution_03_central_limit_theorem/03_central_limit_theorem/12_binom_less_v3

video

We determine the mean and standard deviation of the binomial distribution. \[\mu ~=~ np ~=~ (169)(0.33) ~=~ 55.77\] \[\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{np(1-p)} ~=~ \sqrt{(169)(0.33)(0.67)} ~=~ 6.1127653 \]

We determine a \(z\)-score. (In the de Moivre-Laplace notes, I used \(\sum x\) to emphasize that a binomial variable is a sum of Bernoulli trials. Here, I will just use \(x\) as the boundary for number of successes, because this is the more common notation.) \[\begin{aligned} z &= \frac{x - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{50.5-55.77}{6.1127653} \\\\ &= -0.8621303 \end{aligned}\]

Then, find the standard normal probability.

\[P(Z < -0.8621303) ~=~ 0.1943079 \]

Of course, you could have rounded \(z\), so the following will also get credit. \[P(Z < -0.87) ~=~ 0.1922 \] \[P(Z < -0.86) ~=~ 0.1949 \]
